awd_abstract_narration:
"Advancing Women's Education in STEM (AWE-STEM)" addresses the national need to prepare more women for careers in STEM. The project plans to provide scholarships to three cohorts of twelve students over five years. AWE-STEM scholars will have the opportunity to participate in several high impact activities, including STEM summer workshops, research activities on- and off-campus, field trips, seminars, and an introduction to STEM professional experiences through an annual speaker series. As a women's institution producing a high number of K-12 science teachers Meredith College has the potential to positively influence the number of women pursuing STEM careers as well as have a positive impact on the STEM pipeline through increasing the pool of qualified STEM teachers and providing female role models for young students.

AWE-STEM focuses on three significant issues: the identification of High Impact Practices (HIP) having the greatest impact on student retention overall, the greatest impact on retention of under-represented or low-income students, and the greatest impact on student knowledge gains for underrepresented students as measured by GPA. Cohorts are fostered through a shared first year experience course and an institutional structure in which STEM majors in the same year typically enroll in the same courses. Mentoring events such as dinner at a faculty member's house and other HIP activities are also instrumental to cohort building. Results of the project will be presented at professional meetings of the Mathematical Association of America, the Chemical Education section of the National American Chemical Society, and the American Society of Parasitologists, as well as at the Meredith College's annual Pedagogy, Innovation, and Enhancement workshop.

por.por_cntn:
Less than half of female students who enter science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors during their first year of college will complete degrees in these areas. This number is even lower for students from racial and ethnic minority groups, low-income households, and those who are the first in their families to attend college. For these students, graduation rates in STEM are closer to 25%. Over the past decade, significant efforts have been made to attract and retain these students in STEM majors, but they continue to be underrepresented in STEM fields. A 2023 report from the National Center for Science and Engineering indicated that, in 2021, women made up only 35% of people employed in STEM jobs, while individuals from racial and ethnic minority groups made up about 24% of all STEM workers. In 2020, women and individuals from racial and ethnic minority groups were also still underrepresented among STEM degree recipients at both the undergraduate and graduate levels.

In order to prepare more women for careers in STEM and improve retention of talented female students in STEM majors, the Advancing Women's Education in STEM (AWESTEM) program at Meredith College received grant funding from the National Science Foundation to provide scholarships and enrichment activities for students with financial need. The program aimed to enhance the STEM education of these women and retain them in STEM majors through graduation, improving their opportunities to pursue employment or graduate study in STEM fields. Examples of provided enrichment activities include a STEM focused first year experience course, group bonding events, a STEM Summer Institute, group mentoring events, opportunities for summer research, career planning events, and seminars with guest speakers in STEM professions. 

The first three cohorts of AWESTEM scholars (2018-2020) have completed the program. Thirty-seven young women were in these first three cohorts, 17% of whom were from racial or ethnic minority groups. Over half of the students were from rural environments with 17% also being the first in their families to attend college. The AWESTEM program was successful in retaining female students in STEM majors beyond their first year at a rate that was higher than that of the overall college (see Figure 1). AWESTEM scholars also graduated at equal to or higher rates than the overall college (see Figure 2). Women in the AWESTEM program reported high levels of STEM sense of belonging (Average of 5 on a 6-point scale), a factor shown to contribute to pursuing a STEM career. After graduation, the majority of AWESTEM scholars (81%) also chose to pursue STEM careers or attend STEM graduate programs.

 


Last Modified: 09/10/2024
Modified by: Jennifer Hontz
